\maketitle
\begin{abstract}
We investigate the scaling properties of the Barkhausen effect,
recording the noise in several soft ferromagnetic materials:
polycrystals with different grain sizes and amorphous alloys.  We
measure the Barkhausen avalanche distributions and determine the
scaling exponents. In the limit of vanishing external field rate,
we can group the samples in two distinct classes, characterized
by exponents $\tau = 1.50 \pm0.05$ or $\tau = 1.27 \pm 0.03$, for
the avalanche size distributions. We interpret these results in
terms of the depinning transition of domain walls and obtain an
expression relating  the cutoff of the distributions to the
demagnetizing factor which is in quantitative agreement with
experiments.
\end{abstract}
